JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: I like that.

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: So yes. So after a hard workout now you can celebrate with a brew so bottoms up.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: I never work out that hard. I'm pretty sure of that.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: Sufferfest.

COMPAGNO: Yes. That is the -- kind of the main company there.

(CROSSTALKING)

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: No guy is ever going to drink that beer.

GUTFELD: Sufferfest -- that is a terrible name. I don't want to have a suffer fest.

WILLIAMS: Is that really the name?

PERINO: Is that's what it's called?

COMPAGNO: Yes. Sufferfest.

GUTFELD: All right. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

(CROSSTALKING)

GUTFELD: "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next.

Hello, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hello, Greg.

Juan, where can I get one of those tracksuits?

All right. This is a Fox News alert.

I'm Bret Baier reporting tonight from the White House where the Trump administration continues to push back on impeachment narratives coming from Capitol Hill and from the left as the top polling Democrat prepares to officially enter the race.

But first despite the discord here in Washington post-Mueller report, the markets have taken that report in stride. And tonight your 401(k) is probably a lot healthier than it has been in a while.

A big day on Wall Street as the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ closed at record highs, recovering all the ground they lost in nose dive late last year. The Dow had a strong performance today as well netting 145 closing in on its own record close. The S&P 500 was up 26. The NASDAQ surged 106.

The market is buoyed by better-than-expected numbers from a number of companies today.

Let's get some analysis from Susan Li of the Fox Business Network. She joins us from New York. Good evening -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret.

The bull market continues in 2019, surprising many that thought it was coming to an end especially after a dismal December. The broader index -- the S&P 500 surpassing its last record high struck in September last year. It is also the 81st record under President Trump. The NASDAQ hitting its 96th new record in this administration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: He ended the war on business. He's ended the war on success. He believes strongly that if you do well and succeed you should be rewarded, not punished.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: What has been powering the rally? The Federal Reserve's signaling that the Central Bank is not likely to raise interest rates this year. Also signs that the U.S.-China trade deal will be signed soon and companies earnings that continue to defy gravity. And that is despite bears' (ph) calls for a drop in corporate profits the first three months of the year.

Big tech has been one of the most favorite trade so far with big gains for Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Microsoft. Virtually every sector has seen an advance with stocks big and small joining in on the rally.

A strong stock market and a growing U.S. economy that the President doesn't think gets enough media attention. President Trump tweeting, "In the old days if you are president and you had a good economy you are basically immune from criticism."

Now this week is another big test with tech giants Facebook and Microsoft reporting results tomorrow and first quarter GDP expected on Friday. That is a big one, economist forecasting somewhere between 1.5 percent to maybe 2.5 percent growth -- a strong bounce back after a government shutdown to start off the year -- Bret.

BAIER: Susan Li in New York. Susan, thanks.

President Trump met with the CEO of Twitter here at the White House today. The social media site has been a frequent target of the President's wrath but is also a primary communication tool for him. And case in point, he just tweeted about the meeting last hour. "Great meeting this afternoon at the White House with @Jack from @Twitter. Lots of subjects discussed regarding their platform and the world of social media in general. Look forward to keeping an open dialogue." As you heard Susan mention Twitter was up nearly 16 percent today on the markets because of a positive earnings report.

Meantime one of the President's senior is communicating his thoughts about the ramifications of the Mueller report.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts begins there here on the north lawn. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret, good evening to you.

It was one of those rare moments where we got to hear the first son-in-law Jared Kushner speak at length. It was at the Time 100 Forum where Kushner had plenty to say about the Mueller report and the path that Congress is now taking.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JARED KUSHNER, PRESIDENTIAL SON-IN-LAW: All these people thought Trump was going to lose.

ROBERTS: Weighing in for the first time on the Mueller report, Jared Kushner downplayed Russia's attempts to influence the 2016 election insisting the real damage was done by the ensuing investigation.

KUSHNER: You look at, you know, what Russia did, you know, buying some Facebook ads and tried to (INAUDIBLE) and do it. And it's a terrible thing. But I think the investigations and all the speculation that has happened for the last two years has had a much harsher impact on democracy than a couple of Facebook ads.

ROBERTS: Kushner said when Mueller came calling he was the first one to raise his hand to cooperate. Spending hours with the special counsel, hours more in congressional committees and he fully embraced at least one of Mueller's findings.

KUSHNER: The one thing the Mueller report was very conclusive on is there was absolutely no coordination or collusion with the Trump campaign. And everything that the President has been saying, everything that I've been saying for two years has now been fully authenticated.

ROBERTS: But Democrats want to know a lot more about the other part of the Mueller report -- presidential efforts to thwart the investigation. The White House is deliberating whether to allow former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on May 21st. The former chairman of the committee, Darrell Issa, believes McGahn will testify with conditions.

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: I expect him to come, but I expect him to insist on having people behind him that can advise him as to when to answer a question and when a privilege might be appropriate.

ROBERTS: The White House has already advised one former staffer to ignore a congressional subpoena. Carl Kline, the former chief of White House personnel security was told not to show up for his scheduled deposition to the House Oversight Committee today. Committee chairman Elijah Cummings said he will take a vote to hold Kline in contempt.

Following the lead of Senator Elizabeth Warren, another 2020 Democratic presidential candidate is all in on impeachment. Senator Kamala Harris telling a town hall that Congress needs to act.

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe that we need to get rid of this president. That this president and his administration engaged in obstruction of justice. I believe Congress should take the steps towards impeachment.

ROBERTS: But at the same Time 100 forum where Kushner spoke, President Trump's opponent from 2016 took a more measured approach to the idea of impeachment.

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: You don't put impeachment on the table as the only item on the table and say you're going to get there no matter what which is just what happened in '99.

Instead you say we are going to proceed with the seriousness that this demands.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: And Hillary Clinton knows all too well what happens when Congress barrels down that road to impeachment unimpeded. But at the same time as all these congressional investigations are heating up President Trump will have a chance to get out of Washington for a while.

Just days after he returns from a trip to Japan to meet with the new emperor he will head off to the U.K. to meet with the Queen then cross the channel into Normandy to commemorate the 75th anniversary of D-Day -- Bret.

BAIER: And he'll have a decision -- how much to fight, how much not to fight Congress.

ROBERTS: I have a feeling they're going to fight all -- most if not all of these subpoenas. I think the Kline subpoena fight is a good indication of which way they are going.

BAIER: All right. John -- thank you.

Well, senior officials at the Treasury Department are still trying to determine if a request for the President's tax returns by the House Ways and Means Committee is legal. The Department missed today's deadline to turn over six years of the President's records. The Treasury says it is waiting on the Justice Department to issue a report on the legality. That conclusion will not be given to Treasury until May 6th. The Treasury Secretary insisting the law does not allow Congress to set a deadline for the response.

Meantime a new alarm bells are sounding in Washington tonight over the long-term viability of the nation's bedrock social safety net programs for older Americans. We first told you last night about a new government report stating that Medicare will become insolvent in just seven years if nothing is done. And trustees write that Social Security is in trouble too, following close behind on insolvency.

Tonight correspondent Kevin Corke looks at where we are and what it means.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEEMA VERMA, CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES: The Medicare trustees reported that the Medicare Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is projected to be depleted by 2026.

The 2019 status of the Social Security and Medicare programs paints an alarming picture of the future of two of America's most indispensable entitlement programs.

VERMA: We need to change the trajectory of health care cost growth to ensure the solvency of Medicare and Medicaid.

CORKE: The report summarizes that at current projections Medicare's Hospital Insurance Fund will only be able to afford 89 percent of its total cost in just seven years. And that Social Security program costs are likely to exceed total income in 2020 for the first time since 1982.

While Medicare and specifically Medicare for all have been the subject of a fierce political debate among Democrats this year, Trump administration officials say the program is also increasingly vulnerable. With Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar writing in a statement that instead of trying to expand Medicare into quote, "a universal entitlement that even covers wealthy Americans of working age, we need to fulfill Medicare's promise to our seniors."

SENATOR BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The American people want and we are going to deliver a Medicare for all single-payer system.

CORKE: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders headlines a large field of 2020 Democrat contenders who back some form of Medicare for all with Sanders specifically advocating a single-payer system --

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They're going to will hurt your Social Security so badly.

CORKE: According to the report the news is equally bleak for Social Security. It forecast that its funds could be depleted by 2035 and that could lead to reductions in payouts to retirees and other beneficiaries.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Bret -- the real concern at Social Security offices like the one behind me is that with so many baby boomers nearing retirement age and soon to be drawing off the system, it is paramount that something be done to address the shortfall.

For its part the White House is asking congressional lawmakers to do something about it sooner rather than later -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin -- thank you.

Now to politics. Former vice president Joe Biden will formally declare his candidacy for the top job Thursday. That is a departure from the earlier plan of a Wednesday rollout and it comes as most polls indicate Biden leads the field of which he's not yet an official member.

Correspondent Peter Doocy tells us where things stand right now.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The long time politician who loves quoting Irish poets.

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You know, I can't let a comment go by without quoting an Irish poet.

DOOCY: The third time is a charm. Joe Biden will announce another White House campaign with an online video Thursday, then a Pittsburgh rally Monday. The 2020 bid follows a campaign in 1988 cut short by a plagiarism scandal and a campaign in 2008 that ended after the Iowa caucus.

BIDEN: And let me make something clear to you, I ain't going away.

DOOCY: Now the 76-year-old is set to become 2020's 20th candidate.

HARRIS: Come on in. The water is warm -- Joe.

DOOCY: Kamala Harris is also pitching executive action on guns.

HARRIS: Upon being elected I will give the United States Congress 100 days to get their act together and have the courage to pass reasonable gun safety laws. And if they fail to do it then I will take executive action.

DOOCY: So what has changed since Biden was Barack Obama's vice president when days after the Boston marathon bombing he condemned the culprit.

BIDEN: Two, twisted, perverted, cowardly, knockoff jihadis here in Boston.

DOOCY: Now, the Democratic front runner among declared candidates believes the surviving Boston bomber should be able to vote from jail.

SANDERS: The right to vote is inherent to our democracy. Yes, even for terrible people.

DOOCY: One thing Biden has going for him -- name recognition. Millions already know his story.

Amy Klobuchar isn't quite there yet.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: I like that.

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: So yes. So after a hard workout now you can celebrate with a brew so bottoms up.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: I never work out that hard. I'm pretty sure of that.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: Sufferfest.

COMPAGNO: Yes. That is the -- kind of the main company there.

(CROSSTALKING)

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: No guy is ever going to drink that beer.

GUTFELD: Sufferfest -- that is a terrible name. I don't want to have a suffer fest.

WILLIAMS: Is that really the name?

PERINO: Is that's what it's called?

COMPAGNO: Yes. Sufferfest.

GUTFELD: All right. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

(CROSSTALKING)

GUTFELD: "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next.

Hello, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hello, Greg.

Juan, where can I get one of those tracksuits?

All right. This is a Fox News alert.

I'm Bret Baier reporting tonight from the White House where the Trump administration continues to push back on impeachment narratives coming from Capitol Hill and from the left as the top polling Democrat prepares to officially enter the race.

But first despite the discord here in Washington post-Mueller report, the markets have taken that report in stride. And tonight your 401(k) is probably a lot healthier than it has been in a while.

A big day on Wall Street as the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ closed at record highs, recovering all the ground they lost in nose dive late last year. The Dow had a strong performance today as well netting 145 closing in on its own record close. The S&P 500 was up 26. The NASDAQ surged 106.

The market is buoyed by better-than-expected numbers from a number of companies today.

Let's get some analysis from Susan Li of the Fox Business Network. She joins us from New York. Good evening -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret.

The bull market continues in 2019, surprising many that thought it was coming to an end especially after a dismal December. The broader index -- the S&P 500 surpassing its last record high struck in September last year. It is also the 81st record under President Trump. The NASDAQ hitting its 96th new record in this administration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: He ended the war on business. He's ended the war on success. He believes strongly that if you do well and succeed you should be rewarded, not punished.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: What has been powering the rally? The Federal Reserve's signaling that the Central Bank is not likely to raise interest rates this year. Also signs that the U.S.-China trade deal will be signed soon and companies earnings that continue to defy gravity. And that is despite bears' (ph) calls for a drop in corporate profits the first three months of the year.

Big tech has been one of the most favorite trade so far with big gains for Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Microsoft. Virtually every sector has seen an advance with stocks big and small joining in on the rally.

A strong stock market and a growing U.S. economy that the President doesn't think gets enough media attention. President Trump tweeting, "In the old days if you are president and you had a good economy you are basically immune from criticism."

Now this week is another big test with tech giants Facebook and Microsoft reporting results tomorrow and first quarter GDP expected on Friday. That is a big one, economist forecasting somewhere between 1.5 percent to maybe 2.5 percent growth -- a strong bounce back after a government shutdown to start off the year -- Bret.

BAIER: Susan Li in New York. Susan, thanks.

President Trump met with the CEO of Twitter here at the White House today. The social media site has been a frequent target of the President's wrath but is also a primary communication tool for him. And case in point, he just tweeted about the meeting last hour. "Great meeting this afternoon at the White House with @Jack from @Twitter. Lots of subjects discussed regarding their platform and the world of social media in general. Look forward to keeping an open dialogue." As you heard Susan mention Twitter was up nearly 16 percent today on the markets because of a positive earnings report.

Meantime one of the President's senior is communicating his thoughts about the ramifications of the Mueller report.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts begins there here on the north lawn. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret, good evening to you.

It was one of those rare moments where we got to hear the first son-in-law Jared Kushner speak at length. It was at the Time 100 Forum where Kushner had plenty to say about the Mueller report and the path that Congress is now taking.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JARED KUSHNER, PRESIDENTIAL SON-IN-LAW: All these people thought Trump was going to lose.

ROBERTS: Weighing in for the first time on the Mueller report, Jared Kushner downplayed Russia's attempts to influence the 2016 election insisting the real damage was done by the ensuing investigation.

KUSHNER: You look at, you know, what Russia did, you know, buying some Facebook ads and tried to (INAUDIBLE) and do it. And it's a terrible thing. But I think the investigations and all the speculation that has happened for the last two years has had a much harsher impact on democracy than a couple of Facebook ads.

ROBERTS: Kushner said when Mueller came calling he was the first one to raise his hand to cooperate. Spending hours with the special counsel, hours more in congressional committees and he fully embraced at least one of Mueller's findings.

KUSHNER: The one thing the Mueller report was very conclusive on is there was absolutely no coordination or collusion with the Trump campaign. And everything that the President has been saying, everything that I've been saying for two years has now been fully authenticated.

ROBERTS: But Democrats want to know a lot more about the other part of the Mueller report -- presidential efforts to thwart the investigation. The White House is deliberating whether to allow former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on May 21st. The former chairman of the committee, Darrell Issa, believes McGahn will testify with conditions.

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: I expect him to come, but I expect him to insist on having people behind him that can advise him as to when to answer a question and when a privilege might be appropriate.

ROBERTS: The White House has already advised one former staffer to ignore a congressional subpoena. Carl Kline, the former chief of White House personnel security was told not to show up for his scheduled deposition to the House Oversight Committee today. Committee chairman Elijah Cummings said he will take a vote to hold Kline in contempt.

Following the lead of Senator Elizabeth Warren, another 2020 Democratic presidential candidate is all in on impeachment. Senator Kamala Harris telling a town hall that Congress needs to act.

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe that we need to get rid of this president. That this president and his administration engaged in obstruction of justice. I believe Congress should take the steps towards impeachment.

ROBERTS: But at the same Time 100 forum where Kushner spoke, President Trump's opponent from 2016 took a more measured approach to the idea of impeachment.

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: You don't put impeachment on the table as the only item on the table and say you're going to get there no matter what which is just what happened in '99.

Instead you say we are going to proceed with the seriousness that this demands.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: And Hillary Clinton knows all too well what happens when Congress barrels down that road to impeachment unimpeded. But at the same time as all these congressional investigations are heating up President Trump will have a chance to get out of Washington for a while.

Just days after he returns from a trip to Japan to meet with the new emperor he will head off to the U.K. to meet with the Queen then cross the channel into Normandy to commemorate the 75th anniversary of D-Day -- Bret.

BAIER: And he'll have a decision -- how much to fight, how much not to fight Congress.

ROBERTS: I have a feeling they're going to fight all -- most if not all of these subpoenas. I think the Kline subpoena fight is a good indication of which way they are going.

BAIER: All right. John -- thank you.

Well, senior officials at the Treasury Department are still trying to determine if a request for the President's tax returns by the House Ways and Means Committee is legal. The Department missed today's deadline to turn over six years of the President's records. The Treasury says it is waiting on the Justice Department to issue a report on the legality. That conclusion will not be given to Treasury until May 6th. The Treasury Secretary insisting the law does not allow Congress to set a deadline for the response.

Meantime a new alarm bells are sounding in Washington tonight over the long-term viability of the nation's bedrock social safety net programs for older Americans. We first told you last night about a new government report stating that Medicare will become insolvent in just seven years if nothing is done. And trustees write that Social Security is in trouble too, following close behind on insolvency.

Tonight correspondent Kevin Corke looks at where we are and what it means.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEEMA VERMA, CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES: The Medicare trustees reported that the Medicare Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is projected to be depleted by 2026.

The 2019 status of the Social Security and Medicare programs paints an alarming picture of the future of two of America's most indispensable entitlement programs.

VERMA: We need to change the trajectory of health care cost growth to ensure the solvency of Medicare and Medicaid.

CORKE: The report summarizes that at current projections Medicare's Hospital Insurance Fund will only be able to afford 89 percent of its total cost in just seven years. And that Social Security program costs are likely to exceed total income in 2020 for the first time since 1982.

While Medicare and specifically Medicare for all have been the subject of a fierce political debate among Democrats this year, Trump administration officials say the program is also increasingly vulnerable. With Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar writing in a statement that instead of trying to expand Medicare into quote, "a universal entitlement that even covers wealthy Americans of working age, we need to fulfill Medicare's promise to our seniors."

SENATOR BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The American people want and we are going to deliver a Medicare for all single-payer system.

CORKE: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders headlines a large field of 2020 Democrat contenders who back some form of Medicare for all with Sanders specifically advocating a single-payer system --

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They're going to will hurt your Social Security so badly.

CORKE: According to the report the news is equally bleak for Social Security. It forecast that its funds could be depleted by 2035 and that could lead to reductions in payouts to retirees and other beneficiaries.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Bret -- the real concern at Social Security offices like the one behind me is that with so many baby boomers nearing retirement age and soon to be drawing off the system, it is paramount that something be done to address the shortfall.

For its part the White House is asking congressional lawmakers to do something about it sooner rather than later -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin -- thank you.

Now to politics. Former vice president Joe Biden will formally declare his candidacy for the top job Thursday. That is a departure from the earlier plan of a Wednesday rollout and it comes as most polls indicate Biden leads the field of which he's not yet an official member.

Correspondent Peter Doocy tells us where things stand right now.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The long time politician who loves quoting Irish poets.

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You know, I can't let a comment go by without quoting an Irish poet.

DOOCY: The third time is a charm. Joe Biden will announce another White House campaign with an online video Thursday, then a Pittsburgh rally Monday. The 2020 bid follows a campaign in 1988 cut short by a plagiarism scandal and a campaign in 2008 that ended after the Iowa caucus.

BIDEN: And let me make something clear to you, I ain't going away.

DOOCY: Now the 76-year-old is set to become 2020's 20th candidate.

HARRIS: Come on in. The water is warm -- Joe.

DOOCY: Kamala Harris is also pitching executive action on guns.

HARRIS: Upon being elected I will give the United States Congress 100 days to get their act together and have the courage to pass reasonable gun safety laws. And if they fail to do it then I will take executive action.

DOOCY: So what has changed since Biden was Barack Obama's vice president when days after the Boston marathon bombing he condemned the culprit.

BIDEN: Two, twisted, perverted, cowardly, knockoff jihadis here in Boston.

DOOCY: Now, the Democratic front runner among declared candidates believes the surviving Boston bomber should be able to vote from jail.

SANDERS: The right to vote is inherent to our democracy. Yes, even for terrible people.

DOOCY: One thing Biden has going for him -- name recognition. Millions already know his story.

Amy Klobuchar isn't quite there yet.

SENATOR AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MN), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I have won every single congressional district in my state including Michelle Bachmann's. That is when you guys are supposed to cheer, ok.

DOOCY: One challenge for Biden maybe be generational. He's more than twice the age of surging South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg who just updated his Web site with policy positions but approached accusations that he has pushed a hate hoax by attacking Mike Pence with caution.

MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I'm not a master fisherman but I know bait when I see it and I'm not going to take it.

DOOCY: Joe Biden will bring less of a filter even when facing controversy.

BIDEN: By the way, he gave me permission to touch him, all right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOOCY: As Biden's unwanted touching scandal grew Barack Obama never publicly defended him and now as Biden reportedly plans to roll out a long list of high-profile endorsements, it is not clear Obama will be one of them -- Bret.

BAIER: Peter -- thank you.

We are happy to announce Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg will appear on a Fox News town hall meeting next month. The South Bend, Indiana mayor will join us from Claremont, New Hampshire Sunday May 19th at 7:00 p.m. Eastern. Chris Wallace will moderate that.

We will also host Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar Wednesday May 8th from Milwaukee. That airs at 6:30 p.m. Martha MacCallum and I will moderate that town hall.

Now to the Republicans and the possibility of a second primary challenger to President Trump. He is Maryland Governor Larry Hogan and he showed up today at a perfect spot to get the word out that he may be considering a run.

Correspondent Kristin Fisher shows us tonight from Manchester, New Hampshire.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GOVERNOR LARRY HOGAN (R), MARYLAND: I just thought that April would be a beautiful time to visit New Hampshire.

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maryland Governor Larry Logan played coy about his intentions in attending a must stop event for presidential candidates in the first primary state. But over politics and eggs, the governor made clear he is seriously considering challenging President Trump.

HOGAN: I'm not interested in just running to hurt the President, bruise the President. I'm out here talking about things that I think are important. I care about the future of my party.

FISHER: But the Republican National Committee does not care for any Republican trying to take down President Trump including former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld who officially entered the race last week.

RONNA MCDANIEL, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: They have the right to jump in and lose. That's fine. They will lose horribly. I mean the President has 93 percent approval in our party.

FISHER: In January the Republican National Committee passed a resolution of undivided support for President Trump effectively merging the party and his reelection team into a single unit.

HOGAN: Yes. I think this goes way beyond what the DNC did back in 2016. I think they have taken way more steps to try to stack the deck in favor of the President. I mean I think it was wrong what the DNC did but this is much worse.

FISHER: Today Hogan accused President Trump of trying to commit a crime, obstruction of justice. And he slammed other Republicans for being too afraid to speak out.

Governor Weld agrees.

BILL WELD (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: They are all petrified of the President because they know he can't control his emotions and he's given to temper tantrums and being vindictive.

FISHER: Hogan is aware that after today he could become President Trump's next target. But Hogan believes he is uniquely qualified to sustain that kind of attack.

HOGAN: I battled cancer for 18 months. I can probably take him.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FISHER: But could he upend more than a century of history. The last time a primary challenger defeated a sitting president was in 1884 -- Bret.

BAIER: Kristin Fisher in Manchester, New Hampshire. Kristin -- thanks.

The fate of a proposed citizenship question on next year's census is now in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court. Justices they heard arguments today right now.

Fox News chief legal correspondent and anchor of "FOX NEWS @NIGHT" Shannon Bream tells us what was said today.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DALE HO, ACLU VOTING RIGHTS PROJECT: It is not about a line on a form. It is about whether or not everyone in America counts.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHIEF LEGAL CORRESPONDENT: But therein lies the problem the nine justices must untangle. Whether Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross overstepped his authority by adding a citizenship question to the 2020 sentence.

Critics of the move say it will discourage people from completing the forms predicting it will lead to an undercount of primarily minority populations. Today several of the liberal-leaning justices said the administration can get the information it is seeking from other government databases.

Of Ross' decision Justice Sotomayor said, quote, "This seems like he thought of something, I want to add a citizenship question." Adding, "This is a solution in search of a problem. I've got to find a problem that fits what I want to do."

But a number of the more conservative justices noted that the citizenship question has been included on various census forms nearly uniformly between 1820 and 1950. And in a more limited way since then.

Justice Kavanaugh noting that the statute passed by Congress gives the Commerce Secretary enormous discretion in putting together the census form. Asked why if Congress objects it hasn't already outlawed the question. Quote, "Why doesn't Congress prohibit the asking of a citizenship question in the same way that Congress has explicitly provided that no one can be compelled to provide religious information?"

Opponents traced the entire debate back to the issue of immigration and claimed that the administration's sole purpose in asking about citizenship is to silence people in the U.S. illegally. The administration says the President's priorities are both legal and fair.

HOGAN GIDLEY, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: We want to know who's in this country. And I think as a sovereign nation we have that right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: Well, a decision from the court is due by late June and time is of the essence. The census forms, whether they contain the citizenship question or not will head to the printing process this summer -- Bret.

BAIER: Shannon -- thank you. See you at 11:00 p.m. tonight.

Up next, ISIS claims responsibility for the Easter Sunday massacre on Christians in Sri Lanka.

First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 25 in Boston where a Florida judge has ordered a video police say shows New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft paying for sex not be released publicly for now. The judge accepted arguments by Kraft's attorneys that releasing the video could harm chances for a fair trial. He says it should not be handed to the media as a public record until the jury is seated, a plea agreement is reached or the state drops the case.

And this is a live look at Detroit from Fox 2. The big story there tonight, auto safety regulators expanded investigation into malfunctioning airbag controls to include 12.3 million vehicles. They say the bags may not inflate in a crash. As many as five deaths are already blamed on this problem. The probe covers parts installed in Toyota, Honda, Kia, Hyundai, Mitsubishi and Fiat-Chrysler vehicles from 2010 through 2019 model years.

That is tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Welcome back to a gorgeous night here at the White House.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he wants to name a new settlement in the Golan Heights after President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BENJAMIN NETANYAHU, ISRAELI PRIME MINISTER: All Israelis were deeply moved when President Trump made a start (ph) decision to recognize Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights. Therefore after the Passover holiday I intend to bring to the government a resolution calling for a new community on the Golan Heights named after President Donald J. Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: There has been no reaction, White House reaction so far to Netanyahu's announcement on Twitter.

We are getting new information tonight about who may have been behind the Easter Sunday coordinated blast in Sri Lanka targeting Christians and whether the threat is over. Also getting a look at one of the perpetrators.

Here is correspondent Benjamin Hall.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BENJAMIN HALL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Easter Sunday in Sri Lanka, a suicide bomber walks calmly towards Saint Sebastian's Catholic Church in the heart of the capital right into the very middle of the Easter congregation where he detonates.

The rising death toll now stands at 321 with 500 wounded. Among the dead, four Americans: 11-year-old Kieran Shafritz de Zoysa; 40-year-old, Dieter Kowalski; and siblings Amelie and Daniel Linsey 15 and 19 years old.

There remains a heavy police presence in the city of Colombo as the prime minister warns there were more militants and more bombs out there.

RANIL WICKREMESINGHE, SRI LANKAN PRIME MINISTER: There are few people on the run, some are on the run so we have to apprehend them with the explosives.

HALL: The Sri Lankan government claims the attacks have been in retaliation for last month's shootings at mosques in New Zealand.

GIDLEY: Six bombs within 30 minutes. The coordination quite frankly of this attack and the sophistication, the Sri Lankan government believes that there is international help.

HALL: ISIS is claiming responsibility releasing a video showing the now deceased alleged mastermind, Moulvis Zahran Hashim (ph), surrounded by other suicide bombers who carried out the attack pledging allegiance to ISIS leader Abu Bakr al Baghdadi.

As mass funerals were held, the government has launched an inquiry into intelligence failure after the prime minister said the attack could have been prevented when India handed over specific intelligence ten days ago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HALL: If the attackers did receive help from ISIS it would mark the beginning of a new era for the terror group -- a clear reminder that although they have lost their territorial caliphate they still pose a major threat -- Bret.

BAIER: Benjamin -- thank you.

Up next another legal problem for actor Jussie Smollett.

First beyond our borders tonight. The man in charge of the restoration of the fire-ravaged Notre Dame Cathedral says he has hired professional mountain climbers to install temporary tarps over the building to offset potential rain damage. With showers set to hit the French capital this week the architect in chief says he had to rush the installation of protective covers.

The Northern Ireland police service says it has arrested a woman under the terrorism act in the slaying of journalist Lyra McKee. The 57-year-old female suspect was arrested Tuesday. An Irish Republican Army splinter group earlier admitted one of its volunteers killed McKee. She was fatally shot while reporting on rioting in Londonderry.

Burma's Supreme Court has rejected the final appeal of two Reuters' journalists and upheld seven-year prison sentences for their reporting on the military's brutal crackdown on the Rohingya Muslims. The reporters were arrested in December of 2017 and sentenced last September after being accused of illegally possessing official documents. Today's decision is being criticized by human rights advocates around the world.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We will be right back to the White House.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: You're looking live there at the White House lawn. Alex Jones, the controversial host, Trump supporter, out there with a bullhorn, and that's what you heard earlier. Some people out there as well, saying they support President Trump but they don't support Twitter. President Trump meeting with the CEO of Twitter, Jack Dorsey, here at the White House today. You kind of hear the bullhorn in the background. Thought we'd show you what was happening.

In the meantime, a new legal challenge for embattled actor Jussie Smollett tonight. Two of the men involved in what police say was a faked hate crime attacker are now throwing rhetorical punches at Smollett's lawyers. Senior Correspondent Mike Tobin has details tonight from this story that is ever-changing in Chicago. Good evening, Mike.

MIKE TOBIN, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret. One way or the other we might still see actor Jussie Smollett in a real-life courtroom drama. He is facing a lawsuit from the city of Chicago, and he may very well be called as a witness in the federal lawsuit that was filed today.

However, the actor was not named as a defendant. The suit does say the attack was a hoax conceived and directed by Jussie Smollett right down to the use of a noose, bleach, and shouts that this is MAGA correspondent from the attackers. The lawsuit is directed as his high-powered legal team, Mark Geragos and Tina Glandian. It claims after charges were dropped against Jussie Smollett, Geragos and Glandian did the rounds on news programs and podcasts. Lawyers for the Osundairo brothers say Geragos and Glandian repeatedly made false, reprehensible, and damaging statements. The brothers claim their reputation and personal training business were damaged. They also suffered emotional distress.

Today attorney Gloria Schmidt said the two wannabe actors followed the direction of a successful actor, and now they want to clear their names.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GLORIA SCHMIDT, OSUNDAIRO BROTHERS ATTORNEY: They were asked to do something by a friend who they trusted, and at the end of the day that friend betrayed their trust.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TOBIN: Geragos and Glandian hit back. Part of their statement reads, "This so-called lawsuit by the brothers is more of their lawyer driven nonsense, and a desperate attempt for them to stay relevant and further profit from an attack they admit they perpetrated." Geragos says the suit will be thrown out, it lacks legal footing. The brothers are seeking an unspecified amount of money and legal costs. Bret?

BAIER: Mike Tobin in Chicago. We'll follow this. Mike, thanks.

Meantime, Mexico is trying to show the U.S. it is getting more serious about stopping Central American migrants from reaching the southern border of the U.S. Chief Correspondent Jonathan Hunt looks at a major move that took place Monday.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CHIEF CORRESPONDENT: Migrants fought back with sticks against what appeared to be a concerted effort by Mexican authorities to send a signal they will no longer be so accommodating to the thousands coming from Central America and heading to the U.S. border. It was clearly a well-planned operation with police officers, according to A.P. reporters on scene, suggesting a group of hundreds of migrants take a break in the shade, as others from the approximately 3,000 strong caravan moved on. Then as the trailing group rested, the Mexican authorities moved in. Large numbers of officers grabbing men, women, and children, taking them away to waiting buses. More than 350 were picked up in total according to Mexico's National Migration Institute, which blamed the violence on a small group of aggressive migrants. Journalists traveling with a caravans have also reportedly that migrants are getting a far less hospitable welcome in the Mexican towns they travel through than was the case several months ago.

KEVIN MCALEENAN, ACTING HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: Any solution we're going to have to reduce this flow is going to rely on Mexican authorities to take a stronger action, frankly, against people that are exploiting migrants.

HUNT: Customs and Border Protection officials also shared this video with FOX News today which they say was shot on the Arizona-Mexico border on Saturday, and shows heavily armed smugglers escorting a Guatemalan woman and boy into the U.S. CBP says it is concerned to see those sort of weapons now being used by human smugglers right on the border.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HUNT: The woman and her son were quickly detained by CBP agents. The armed smugglers are still at large somewhere in Mexico. Bret?

BAIER: Jonathan, thank you.

Joe Biden pushes back his entry into the 2020 race by a day, and President Trump may be getting another Republican challenger. We'll talk about it all and the 2020 election when the panel joins me after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, (D-CA) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe Congress should take the steps towards impeachment.

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR, (D-MN) PRESIDENT CANDIDATE: The impeachment proceedings are up to the House. They are going to have to make that decision.

PETE BUTTIGIEG, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I think he has made it pretty clear that he deserves impeachment. I'm also going to leave it to the House and Senate to figure that out.

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN, (D) MASSACHUSETTS: Every person in the Senate and the House, they should take that vote and live with it for the rest of their lives.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I want to see about that investigation. We'll see where it goes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: "Impeachment" the word of the day for the town hall with the 2020 candidates, as you look at a list, a ever-growing of people getting into the 2020 race. It is a lot easier, it seems, for them to say, sure, go ahead and impeach President Trump, than it is for House Democrats to get to that conclusion and the logistical hurdles ahead.

As you look at the polls new out today, Monmouth poll, has Joe Biden is in the lead and you see Bernie Sanders in second. Pete Buttigieg, they mayor, look at that, less that one percent to eight percent just in a short time. And then if you look at Iowa, obviously the first stop the Iowa caucuses, Joe Biden also leading there, the margin a little bit smaller, and Buttigieg, the South Bend, Indiana, mayor in third.

With that, let's bring in our panel tonight, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," Leslie Marshall, Democrat strategist, and Jonah Goldberg, senior editor at "National Review." Jonah, we've had this kind of launch, non-launch for Joe Biden. He was going to go Wednesday, now it's Thursday. We don't have a lot of details on what it looks like, but he's clearly still leading in some of these big pools.

JONAH GOLDBERG, SENIOR EDITOR, "NATIONAL REVIEW": He is. And I think he is well-positioned. I don't usually give a lot advice to Democrats, but if I were him, I would come out, I would announce and immediately take dead aim at Bernie Sanders and say this is a two-person race. I'm the grown up. I'm a liberal, but I'm not a socialist. The party will go down in flames if we pursue Bernie's path. It will make everybody else look small. He is basically the only guy in a position who can do that.

And I think that one of the things we see is that a lot of the Democratic primary people, they think that basically Democratic Twitter is the actual Democratic electorate, and it's not. And he is one of the only people who is positioned to actually reach out to the traditional Democratic voter.

BAIER: Leslie, you do wonder, though, about the launch or decision to launch and what transpired there. All we are told is that something will happen Thursday, a video launch, and then there's a Monday event in Pittsburgh. I don't know what happens between Thursday and Monday, but it's interesting.

LESLIE MARSHALL, RADIO TALK SHOW HOST: Originally it was supposed to be Wednesday, tomorrow, as you know. And one of the reasons they delayed it, I'm being told, is Charlottesville. A lot of people thought at first that might be a good place for the former vice president to announce, but then there was some kickback, people felt it was disrespectful, they decided not to do it, and that delayed them some.

There is a "Time" magazine piece where they have people that are already leaking within the campaign, saying it is very disorganized for a launch, that is a problem that he will have to get on track. But I and other Democrats are not worried yet. He is still leading in almost every poll, and he hasn't yet announced.

BAIER: Charlie, a lot of that has to do with name recognition, a lot of that has to do with eight years as vice president, and you wonder how Joe Biden is going to compete with a pretty energetic and obviously voluminous candidate spread on the Democratic side.

CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "WASHINGTON TIMES": Yes, and of course the problem for Joe Biden both in the Democratic Party and as a general election candidate is the fact that he has been around Washington for 45 years. He has been part of a problem for a for a very, very long time. And so he has -- he is going to struggle to come up with whatever new message it is that he has go that now it is going to change everything.

And of course when I look at the field I can't think of a single person who has actually run for president as many times as he has over the past -- since he has been in Washington. And all of that while, as you point out, the name recognition is very, very good, and it helps them very much. And I think Jonah is right, he is in a position to face off against somebody like Bernie Sanders and show the difference between the two of them. The problem still remains that he has been around here for a very long time, and it's a mess.

BAIER: It doesn't seem like President Trump has settled on a nickname yet. He had one percent Joe for past races, then he had sleepy Joe. We don't know where he will end up.

Jonah, voting rights for prisoners came up last night in the town halls and seemed to be a little bit of a separation. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Should people convicted of sexual assault, the Boston Marathon bomber, should they be able to vote?

PETE BUTTIGIEG, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: While incarcerated?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

BUTTIGIEG: No, I don't think so.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I do believe that even if they are in jail, they are paying their price to society, but that should not take away their inherent American right to participate in our democracy.

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, (D-CA) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I think we should have that conversation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Is this an issue that Iowa and New Hampshire cares about?

GOLDBERG: It is a "Saturday Night Live" skit. Buttigieg gave the exact right answer, and Bernie Sanders' position I find utterly baffling. Look, when you go to this thing called prison, you have lots of rights that are curtailed. The freedom of assembly, freedom of speech all sorts of things. One of the others ones happens to be freedom to vote. It is another thing entirely when you pay back your debt to society about whether or not you should have your voting rights restored. But the idea that Bernie Sanders is getting out like free candy these Willie Horton type issues where he wants the worst terrorists in America to be able to vote, it's bizarre to me.

BAIER: Leslie, it's one thing to be talking about Medicare for all and the details of that and then the Green New Deal and how you're going to pay for it, but it seems that that, prisoners voting, Electoral College, seem on the outskirts.

MARSHALL: Definitely. In dark corners, if you will, Democrats like myself are saying, why are they even making this an issue? Mayor Pete got it right. When somebody commits a crime, and I think most Democrats feel this way, they lose their rights as a free individual. Now, when they get out of prison, if they get those rights restored that's a whole other conversation. We've seen that. There are people left and right that can agree to that. And this is a can of worms that a Democrat doesn't need to open because we have so many other areas. The only good thing about this, Bret, is this is one area where they all did not agree on this issue.

BAIER: All right, finally, you have William Weld on the Republican side throwing his name in the hat, an uphill battle obviously. Now you have potentially the Maryland governor. Take a listen to Larry Hogan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. LARRY HOGAN, (R) MARYLAND: I think it goes way beyond what the DNC did back in 2016. I think they have taken way more steps to try to stack the deck in favor of the president. I think it was wrong what the DNC did, but this is much worse.

To change the rules and to insist 100 percent royalty to the dear leader, it just didn't sound very much like the Republican Party that I grew up in.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: They have the right to jump in and lose. That's fine. They will lose horribly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Charlie, you don't go to politics in New Hampshire unless you are really thinking about it.

HURT: I think that is right. And by the way, I think it is a great thing. I think anybody wants to get in and stir the pot is great. But the bottom line remains, the president remains one of the most popular Republicans among Republicans in recent times, and he's going to be the nominee. With Bernie Sanders, I'm calling it the 50-state strategy to make sure that even Massachusetts votes for Republicans. With crazy ideas like letting the Boston Marathon bomber's vote, a guy like President Trump is in a good position I think to win reelection.

BAIER: By the way, Alex Jones agrees with you behind the gate here with his microphone. Panel, stand by. Next up, a grim outlook for Medicare and Social Security.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

SEEMA VERMA, CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES: Health care spending in America is on an unsustainable path. The Medicare Trustees reported that the Medicare hospital insurance trust fund is projected to be depleted by 2026.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If you take Social Security, it's 25 percent of the federal budget, and it's growing faster than the GDP. You add in Medicare and Medicaid and now you're up to about 55 percent, 55 percent of the entire federal budget.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: We saw some disturbing numbers from the Trustees report. As you heard Medicare seven years from now depleted in the hospital insurance pond. That happens then Medicare Part A will only be able to cover 89 percent of the cost for hospital stays and related services, and that will go down to 77 percent in 2046. On Social Security, total costs projected to exceed its total income including interests for the first time since 1982. The bottom line is something has to be done to save these programs if we are going to. We are back with a panel. Charlie?

HURT: Yes. This is a slow-rolling catastrophe, and it's not something that we haven't known for a long time. Obviously, people like Paul Ryan have been talking about it for a long time. President Trump obviously ran in 2016 vowing not to touch these programs. Obviously, that was a smart move back then, but the fact remains that they are going consultants and something has to be done about it.

The one good thing I think that has happened is that it's going to be a lot easier to fix these programs with a very good economy like the one we have right now than if we were facing this catastrophe and had a bad economy.

BAIER: Leslie, it doesn't seem like anybody is taking this baton.

MARSHALL: They knew about this at least a year ago. Maybe we have some better numbers today. But look, you have baby boomers that are going to enter the system, more people, and you have people with a double whammy right now, because you have some individuals, my mom is one of them, who rely largely on their Social Security to live. How on earth are they going to make up any kind of a gap with Medicare if they can't afford any secondary insurance beyond what they are already paying? This is something where the left and right, Democrats and Republicans, not only can work together but they have to, and they have to do it before it's on the brink of insolvency.

BAIER: But the difference is pretty stark. The White House reaction is this report is grim, but Medicare for all is not the answer.

GOLDBERG: And they are right. The thing is the Trump administration has basically ignored the problem with entitlements while the Democrats are proposing things to make them much, much worse. The simple fact is that we live in an economy where Social Security was created when we had something like over a dozen workers for every retiree. Most people died at 61, they didn't get benefits until they were 65. Now it's two-to-one per retiree. We're having a massive wealth transfer from young people to old people. It is not sustainable. It has got to be ripped up from the ground and figured out. You have to grandfather in the people who are recipients now but then fix it for the coming generation. That is nowhere on the horizon for what the Democrats are proposing, and the Republicans are just ignoring it.

BAIER: Charlie, Medicare for all seems to be a litmus test for a lot of Democrats running this year.

HURT: Yes, and unfortunately the idea of Medicare for all on top of the problems that we're facing right now is the typical government answer, more centralized governance from Washington. That is the whole problem in the first place. Making Medicare, expanding it massively, isn't going to fix it. It's going to break it.

BAIER: Panel, thank you.

Just moments ago, the president tweeted, "You mean the stock market hit an all-time record high today and they are actually talking impeachment? Will I ever be given credit for anything by the fake news media or radical liberal Dems? No collusion!" We obviously lead with that news tonight on the newscast tonight. The president is welcome. We're here a lot of Tuesdays down here on the North Lawn. Any time.

When we come back, one brave police officer confronts a situation that could really stink things up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Nothing like a sunset at the White House.

Finally tonight, Police Officer Ron Kaszas in South Bend, Indiana, managed to pull off quite the rescue for one lucky skunk.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I bet you this will go viral.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Not in the car.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Look at those South Bend police officers. They are always doing something good.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The skunk had a cup on its head, in case you didn't see that. There you go.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That is it for the SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and still unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now.

END

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: I like that.

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: So yes. So after a hard workout now you can celebrate with a brew so bottoms up.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: I never work out that hard. I'm pretty sure of that.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: Sufferfest.

COMPAGNO: Yes. That is the -- kind of the main company there.

(CROSSTALKING)

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: No guy is ever going to drink that beer.

GUTFELD: Sufferfest -- that is a terrible name. I don't want to have a suffer fest.

WILLIAMS: Is that really the name?

PERINO: Is that's what it's called?

COMPAGNO: Yes. Sufferfest.

GUTFELD: All right. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

(CROSSTALKING)

GUTFELD: "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next.

Hello, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hello, Greg.

Juan, where can I get one of those tracksuits?

All right. This is a Fox News alert.

I'm Bret Baier reporting tonight from the White House where the Trump administration continues to push back on impeachment narratives coming from Capitol Hill and from the left as the top polling Democrat prepares to officially enter the race.

But first despite the discord here in Washington post-Mueller report, the markets have taken that report in stride. And tonight your 401(k) is probably a lot healthier than it has been in a while.

A big day on Wall Street as the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ closed at record highs, recovering all the ground they lost in nose dive late last year. The Dow had a strong performance today as well netting 145 closing in on its own record close. The S&P 500 was up 26. The NASDAQ surged 106.

The market is buoyed by better-than-expected numbers from a number of companies today.

Let's get some analysis from Susan Li of the Fox Business Network. She joins us from New York. Good evening -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret.

The bull market continues in 2019, surprising many that thought it was coming to an end especially after a dismal December. The broader index -- the S&P 500 surpassing its last record high struck in September last year. It is also the 81st record under President Trump. The NASDAQ hitting its 96th new record in this administration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: He ended the war on business. He's ended the war on success. He believes strongly that if you do well and succeed you should be rewarded, not punished.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: What has been powering the rally? The Federal Reserve's signaling that the Central Bank is not likely to raise interest rates this year. Also signs that the U.S.-China trade deal will be signed soon and companies earnings that continue to defy gravity. And that is despite bears' (ph) calls for a drop in corporate profits the first three months of the year.

Big tech has been one of the most favorite trade so far with big gains for Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Microsoft. Virtually every sector has seen an advance with stocks big and small joining in on the rally.

A strong stock market and a growing U.S. economy that the President doesn't think gets enough media attention. President Trump tweeting, "In the old days if you are president and you had a good economy you are basically immune from criticism."

Now this week is another big test with tech giants Facebook and Microsoft reporting results tomorrow and first quarter GDP expected on Friday. That is a big one, economist forecasting somewhere between 1.5 percent to maybe 2.5 percent growth -- a strong bounce back after a government shutdown to start off the year -- Bret.

BAIER: Susan Li in New York. Susan, thanks.

President Trump met with the CEO of Twitter here at the White House today. The social media site has been a frequent target of the President's wrath but is also a primary communication tool for him. And case in point, he just tweeted about the meeting last hour. "Great meeting this afternoon at the White House with @Jack from @Twitter. Lots of subjects discussed regarding their platform and the world of social media in general. Look forward to keeping an open dialogue." As you heard Susan mention Twitter was up nearly 16 percent today on the markets because of a positive earnings report.

Meantime one of the President's senior is communicating his thoughts about the ramifications of the Mueller report.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts begins there here on the north lawn. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret, good evening to you.

It was one of those rare moments where we got to hear the first son-in-law Jared Kushner speak at length. It was at the Time 100 Forum where Kushner had plenty to say about the Mueller report and the path that Congress is now taking.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JARED KUSHNER, PRESIDENTIAL SON-IN-LAW: All these people thought Trump was going to lose.

ROBERTS: Weighing in for the first time on the Mueller report, Jared Kushner downplayed Russia's attempts to influence the 2016 election insisting the real damage was done by the ensuing investigation.

KUSHNER: You look at, you know, what Russia did, you know, buying some Facebook ads and tried to (INAUDIBLE) and do it. And it's a terrible thing. But I think the investigations and all the speculation that has happened for the last two years has had a much harsher impact on democracy than a couple of Facebook ads.

ROBERTS: Kushner said when Mueller came calling he was the first one to raise his hand to cooperate. Spending hours with the special counsel, hours more in congressional committees and he fully embraced at least one of Mueller's findings.

KUSHNER: The one thing the Mueller report was very conclusive on is there was absolutely no coordination or collusion with the Trump campaign. And everything that the President has been saying, everything that I've been saying for two years has now been fully authenticated.

ROBERTS: But Democrats want to know a lot more about the other part of the Mueller report -- presidential efforts to thwart the investigation. The White House is deliberating whether to allow former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on May 21st. The former chairman of the committee, Darrell Issa, believes McGahn will testify with conditions.

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: I expect him to come, but I expect him to insist on having people behind him that can advise him as to when to answer a question and when a privilege might be appropriate.

ROBERTS: The White House has already advised one former staffer to ignore a congressional subpoena. Carl Kline, the former chief of White House personnel security was told not to show up for his scheduled deposition to the House Oversight Committee today. Committee chairman Elijah Cummings said he will take a vote to hold Kline in contempt.

Following the lead of Senator Elizabeth Warren, another 2020 Democratic presidential candidate is all in on impeachment. Senator Kamala Harris telling a town hall that Congress needs to act.

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe that we need to get rid of this president. That this president and his administration engaged in obstruction of justice. I believe Congress should take the steps towards impeachment.

ROBERTS: But at the same Time 100 forum where Kushner spoke, President Trump's opponent from 2016 took a more measured approach to the idea of impeachment.

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: You don't put impeachment on the table as the only item on the table and say you're going to get there no matter what which is just what happened in '99.

GOLDBERG: And they are right. The thing is the Trump administration has basically ignored the problem with entitlements while the Democrats are proposing things to make them much, much worse. The simple fact is that we live in an economy where Social Security was created when we had something like over a dozen workers for every retiree. Most people died at 61, they didn't get benefits until they were 65. Now it's two-to-one per retiree. We're having a massive wealth transfer from young people to old people. It is not sustainable. It has got to be ripped up from the ground and figured out. You have to grandfather in the people who are recipients now but then fix it for the coming generation. That is nowhere on the horizon for what the Democrats are proposing, and the Republicans are just ignoring it.

BAIER: Charlie, Medicare for all seems to be a litmus test for a lot of Democrats running this year.

HURT: Yes, and unfortunately the idea of Medicare for all on top of the problems that we're facing right now is the typical government answer, more centralized governance from Washington. That is the whole problem in the first place. Making Medicare, expanding it massively, isn't going to fix it. It's going to break it.

BAIER: Panel, thank you.

Just moments ago, the president tweeted, "You mean the stock market hit an all-time record high today and they are actually talking impeachment? Will I ever be given credit for anything by the fake news media or radical liberal Dems? No collusion!" We obviously lead with that news tonight on the newscast tonight. The president is welcome. We're here a lot of Tuesdays down here on the North Lawn. Any time.

When we come back, one brave police officer confronts a situation that could really stink things up.

BAIER: Nothing like a sunset at the White House.

Finally tonight, Police Officer Ron Kaszas in South Bend, Indiana, managed to pull off quite the rescue for one lucky skunk.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I bet you this will go viral.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Not in the car.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Look at those South Bend police officers. They are always doing something good.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: The skunk had a cup on its head, in case you didn't see that. There you go.

Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That is it for the SPECIAL REPORT, fair, balanced, and still unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now.
