JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST: I like that.

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: So yes. So after a hard workout now you can celebrate with a brew so bottoms up.

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: I never work out that hard. I'm pretty sure of that.

GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST: Sufferfest.

COMPAGNO: Yes. That is the -- kind of the main company there.

(CROSSTALKING)

JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST: No guy is ever going to drink that beer.

GUTFELD: Sufferfest -- that is a terrible name. I don't want to have a suffer fest.

WILLIAMS: Is that really the name?

PERINO: Is that's what it's called?

COMPAGNO: Yes. Sufferfest.

GUTFELD: All right. Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

(CROSSTALKING)

GUTFELD: "SPECIAL REPORT" is up next.

Hello, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hello, Greg.

Juan, where can I get one of those tracksuits?

All right. This is a Fox News alert.

I'm Bret Baier reporting tonight from the White House where the Trump administration continues to push back on impeachment narratives coming from Capitol Hill and from the left as the top polling Democrat prepares to officially enter the race.

But first despite the discord here in Washington post-Mueller report, the markets have taken that report in stride. And tonight your 401(k) is probably a lot healthier than it has been in a while.

A big day on Wall Street as the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ closed at record highs, recovering all the ground they lost in nose dive late last year. The Dow had a strong performance today as well netting 145 closing in on its own record close. The S&P 500 was up 26. The NASDAQ surged 106.

The market is buoyed by better-than-expected numbers from a number of companies today.

Let's get some analysis from Susan Li of the Fox Business Network. She joins us from New York. Good evening -- Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Good evening, Bret.

The bull market continues in 2019, surprising many that thought it was coming to an end especially after a dismal December. The broader index -- the S&P 500 surpassing its last record high struck in September last year. It is also the 81st record under President Trump. The NASDAQ hitting its 96th new record in this administration.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL DIRECTOR: He ended the war on business. He's ended the war on success. He believes strongly that if you do well and succeed you should be rewarded, not punished.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: What has been powering the rally? The Federal Reserve's signaling that the Central Bank is not likely to raise interest rates this year. Also signs that the U.S.-China trade deal will be signed soon and companies earnings that continue to defy gravity. And that is despite bears' (ph) calls for a drop in corporate profits the first three months of the year.

Big tech has been one of the most favorite trade so far with big gains for Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Microsoft. Virtually every sector has seen an advance with stocks big and small joining in on the rally.

A strong stock market and a growing U.S. economy that the President doesn't think gets enough media attention. President Trump tweeting, "In the old days if you are president and you had a good economy you are basically immune from criticism."

Now this week is another big test with tech giants Facebook and Microsoft reporting results tomorrow and first quarter GDP expected on Friday. That is a big one, economist forecasting somewhere between 1.5 percent to maybe 2.5 percent growth -- a strong bounce back after a government shutdown to start off the year -- Bret.

BAIER: Susan Li in New York. Susan, thanks.

President Trump met with the CEO of Twitter here at the White House today. The social media site has been a frequent target of the President's wrath but is also a primary communication tool for him. And case in point, he just tweeted about the meeting last hour. "Great meeting this afternoon at the White House with @Jack from @Twitter. Lots of subjects discussed regarding their platform and the world of social media in general. Look forward to keeping an open dialogue." As you heard Susan mention Twitter was up nearly 16 percent today on the markets because of a positive earnings report.

Meantime one of the President's senior is communicating his thoughts about the ramifications of the Mueller report.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts begins there here on the north lawn. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Bret, good evening to you.

It was one of those rare moments where we got to hear the first son-in-law Jared Kushner speak at length. It was at the Time 100 Forum where Kushner had plenty to say about the Mueller report and the path that Congress is now taking.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JARED KUSHNER, PRESIDENTIAL SON-IN-LAW: All these people thought Trump was going to lose.

ROBERTS: Weighing in for the first time on the Mueller report, Jared Kushner downplayed Russia's attempts to influence the 2016 election insisting the real damage was done by the ensuing investigation.

KUSHNER: You look at, you know, what Russia did, you know, buying some Facebook ads and tried to (INAUDIBLE) and do it. And it's a terrible thing. But I think the investigations and all the speculation that has happened for the last two years has had a much harsher impact on democracy than a couple of Facebook ads.

ROBERTS: Kushner said when Mueller came calling he was the first one to raise his hand to cooperate. Spending hours with the special counsel, hours more in congressional committees and he fully embraced at least one of Mueller's findings.

KUSHNER: The one thing the Mueller report was very conclusive on is there was absolutely no coordination or collusion with the Trump campaign. And everything that the President has been saying, everything that I've been saying for two years has now been fully authenticated.

ROBERTS: But Democrats want to know a lot more about the other part of the Mueller report -- presidential efforts to thwart the investigation. The White House is deliberating whether to allow former White House counsel Don McGahn to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on May 21st. The former chairman of the committee, Darrell Issa, believes McGahn will testify with conditions.

REP. DARRELL ISSA (R), CALIFORNIA: I expect him to come, but I expect him to insist on having people behind him that can advise him as to when to answer a question and when a privilege might be appropriate.

ROBERTS: The White House has already advised one former staffer to ignore a congressional subpoena. Carl Kline, the former chief of White House personnel security was told not to show up for his scheduled deposition to the House Oversight Committee today. Committee chairman Elijah Cummings said he will take a vote to hold Kline in contempt.

Following the lead of Senator Elizabeth Warren, another 2020 Democratic presidential candidate is all in on impeachment. Senator Kamala Harris telling a town hall that Congress needs to act.

SENATOR KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I believe that we need to get rid of this president. That this president and his administration engaged in obstruction of justice. I believe Congress should take the steps towards impeachment.

ROBERTS: But at the same Time 100 forum where Kushner spoke, President Trump's opponent from 2016 took a more measured approach to the idea of impeachment.

HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: You don't put impeachment on the table as the only item on the table and say you're going to get there no matter what which is just what happened in '99.

Instead you say we are going to proceed with the seriousness that this demands.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: And Hillary Clinton knows all too well what happens when Congress barrels down that road to impeachment unimpeded. But at the same time as all these congressional investigations are heating up President Trump will have a chance to get out of Washington for a while.

Just days after he returns from a trip to Japan to meet with the new emperor he will head off to the U.K. to meet with the Queen then cross the channel into Normandy to commemorate the 75th anniversary of D-Day -- Bret.

BAIER: And he'll have a decision -- how much to fight, how much not to fight Congress.

ROBERTS: I have a feeling they're going to fight all -- most if not all of these subpoenas. I think the Kline subpoena fight is a good indication of which way they are going.

BAIER: All right. John -- thank you.

Well, senior officials at the Treasury Department are still trying to determine if a request for the President's tax returns by the House Ways and Means Committee is legal. The Department missed today's deadline to turn over six years of the President's records. The Treasury says it is waiting on the Justice Department to issue a report on the legality. That conclusion will not be given to Treasury until May 6th. The Treasury Secretary insisting the law does not allow Congress to set a deadline for the response.

Meantime a new alarm bells are sounding in Washington tonight over the long-term viability of the nation's bedrock social safety net programs for older Americans. We first told you last night about a new government report stating that Medicare will become insolvent in just seven years if nothing is done. And trustees write that Social Security is in trouble too, following close behind on insolvency.

Tonight correspondent Kevin Corke looks at where we are and what it means.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEEMA VERMA, CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES: The Medicare trustees reported that the Medicare Hospital Insurance Trust Fund is projected to be depleted by 2026.

The 2019 status of the Social Security and Medicare programs paints an alarming picture of the future of two of America's most indispensable entitlement programs.

VERMA: We need to change the trajectory of health care cost growth to ensure the solvency of Medicare and Medicaid.

CORKE: The report summarizes that at current projections Medicare's Hospital Insurance Fund will only be able to afford 89 percent of its total cost in just seven years. And that Social Security program costs are likely to exceed total income in 2020 for the first time since 1982.

While Medicare and specifically Medicare for all have been the subject of a fierce political debate among Democrats this year, Trump administration officials say the program is also increasingly vulnerable. With Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar writing in a statement that instead of trying to expand Medicare into quote, "a universal entitlement that even covers wealthy Americans of working age, we need to fulfill Medicare's promise to our seniors."

SENATOR BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: The American people want and we are going to deliver a Medicare for all single-payer system.

CORKE: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders headlines a large field of 2020 Democrat contenders who back some form of Medicare for all with Sanders specifically advocating a single-payer system --

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: They're going to will hurt your Social Security so badly.

CORKE: According to the report the news is equally bleak for Social Security. It forecast that its funds could be depleted by 2035 and that could lead to reductions in payouts to retirees and other beneficiaries.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CORKE: Bret -- the real concern at Social Security offices like the one behind me is that with so many baby boomers nearing retirement age and soon to be drawing off the system, it is paramount that something be done to address the shortfall.

For its part the White House is asking congressional lawmakers to do something about it sooner rather than later -- Bret.

BAIER: Kevin -- thank you.

Now to politics. Former vice president Joe Biden will formally declare his candidacy for the top job Thursday. That is a departure from the earlier plan of a Wednesday rollout and it comes as most polls indicate Biden leads the field of which he's not yet an official member.

Correspondent Peter Doocy tells us where things stand right now.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The long time politician who loves quoting Irish poets.

JOE BIDEN, FORMER VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: You know, I can't let a comment go by without quoting an Irish poet.

DOOCY: The third time is a charm. Joe Biden will announce another White House campaign with an online video Thursday, then a Pittsburgh rally Monday. The 2020 bid follows a campaign in 1988 cut short by a plagiarism scandal and a campaign in 2008 that ended after the Iowa caucus.

BIDEN: And let me make something clear to you, I ain't going away.

DOOCY: Now the 76-year-old is set to become 2020's 20th candidate.

HARRIS: Come on in. The water is warm -- Joe.

DOOCY: Kamala Harris is also pitching executive action on guns.

HARRIS: Upon being elected I will give the United States Congress 100 days to get their act together and have the courage to pass reasonable gun safety laws. And if they fail to do it then I will take executive action.

DOOCY: So what has changed since Biden was Barack Obama's vice president when days after the Boston marathon bombing he condemned the culprit.

BIDEN: Two, twisted, perverted, cowardly, knockoff jihadis here in Boston.

DOOCY: Now, the Democratic front runner among declared candidates believes the surviving Boston bomber should be able to vote from jail.

SANDERS: The right to vote is inherent to our democracy. Yes, even for terrible people.

DOOCY: One thing Biden has going for him -- name recognition. Millions already know his story.

Amy Klobuchar isn't quite there yet.

SENATOR AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MN), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I have won every single congressional district in my state including Michelle Bachmann's. That is when you guys are supposed to cheer, ok.

DOOCY: One challenge for Biden maybe be generational. He's more than twice the age of surging South Bend Mayor Pete Buttigieg who just updated his Web site with policy positions but approached accusations that he has pushed a hate hoax by attacking Mike Pence with caution.

MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I'm not a master fisherman but I know bait when I see it and I'm not going to take it.

DOOCY: Joe Biden will bring less of a filter even when facing controversy.

BIDEN: By the way, he gave me permission to touch him, all right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

DOOCY: As Biden's unwanted touching scandal grew Barack Obama never publicly defended him and now as Biden reportedly plans to roll out a long list of high-profile endorsements, it is not clear Obama will be one of them -- Bret.

BAIER: Peter -- thank you.

We are happy to announce Democratic presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg will appear on a Fox News town hall meeting next month. The South Bend, Indiana mayor will join us from Claremont, New Hampshire Sunday May 19th at 7:00 p.m. Eastern. Chris Wallace will moderate that.

We will also host Minnesota Senator Amy Klobuchar Wednesday May 8th from Milwaukee. That airs at 6:30 p.m. Martha MacCallum and I will moderate that town hall.

Now to the Republicans and the possibility of a second primary challenger to President Trump. He is Maryland Governor Larry Hogan and he showed up today at a perfect spot to get the word out that he may be considering a run.

Correspondent Kristin Fisher shows us tonight from Manchester, New Hampshire.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GOVERNOR LARRY HOGAN (R), MARYLAND: I just thought that April would be a beautiful time to visit New Hampshire.

KRISTIN FISHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Maryland Governor Larry Logan played coy about his intentions in attending a must stop event for presidential candidates in the first primary state. But over politics and eggs, the governor made clear he is seriously considering challenging President Trump.

HOGAN: I'm not interested in just running to hurt the President, bruise the President. I'm out here talking about things that I think are important. I care about the future of my party.

FISHER: But the Republican National Committee does not care for any Republican trying to take down President Trump including former Massachusetts Governor Bill Weld who officially entered the race last week.

RONNA MCDANIEL, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN: They have the right to jump in and lose. That's fine. They will lose horribly. I mean the President has 93 percent approval in our party.

FISHER: In January the Republican National Committee passed a resolution of undivided support for President Trump effectively merging the party and his reelection team into a single unit.

HOGAN: Yes. I think this goes way beyond what the DNC did back in 2016. I think they have taken way more steps to try to stack the deck in favor of the President. I mean I think it was wrong what the DNC did but this is much worse.

FISHER: Today Hogan accused President Trump of trying to commit a crime, obstruction of justice. And he slammed other Republicans for being too afraid to speak out.

Governor Weld agrees.

BILL WELD (R), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: They are all petrified of the President because they know he can't control his emotions and he's given to temper tantrums and being vindictive.

FISHER: Hogan is aware that after today he could become President Trump's next target. But Hogan believes he is uniquely qualified to sustain that kind of attack.

HOGAN: I battled cancer for 18 months. I can probably take him.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FISHER: But could he upend more than a century of history. The last time a primary challenger defeated a sitting president was in 1884 -- Bret.

BAIER: Kristin Fisher in Manchester, New Hampshire. Kristin -- thanks.

The fate of a proposed citizenship question on next year's census is now in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court. Justices they heard arguments today right now.

Fox News chief legal correspondent and anchor of "FOX NEWS @NIGHT" Shannon Bream tells us what was said today.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DALE HO, ACLU VOTING RIGHTS PROJECT: It is not about a line on a form. It is about whether or not everyone in America counts.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHIEF LEGAL CORRESPONDENT: But therein lies the problem the nine justices must untangle. Whether Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross overstepped his authority by adding a citizenship question to the 2020 sentence.

Critics of the move say it will discourage people from completing the forms predicting it will lead to an undercount of primarily minority populations. Today several of the liberal-leaning justices said the administration can get the information it is seeking from other government databases.

Of Ross' decision Justice Sotomayor said, quote, "This seems like he thought of something, I want to add a citizenship question." Adding, "This is a solution in search of a problem. I've got to find a problem that fits what I want to do."

But a number of the more conservative justices noted that the citizenship question has been included on various census forms nearly uniformly between 1820 and 1950. And in a more limited way since then.

Justice Kavanaugh noting that the statute passed by Congress gives the Commerce Secretary enormous discretion in putting together the census form. Asked why if Congress objects it hasn't already outlawed the question. Quote, "Why doesn't Congress prohibit the asking of a citizenship question in the same way that Congress has explicitly provided that no one can be compelled to provide religious information?"

Opponents traced the entire debate back to the issue of immigration and claimed that the administration's sole purpose in asking about citizenship is to silence people in the U.S. illegally. The administration says the President's priorities are both legal and fair.

HOGAN GIDLEY, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: We want to know who's in this country. And I think as a sovereign nation we have that right.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: Well, a decision from the court is due by late June and time is of the essence. The census forms, whether they contain the citizenship question or not will head to the printing process this summer -- Bret.

BAIER: Shannon -- thank you. See you at 11:00 p.m. tonight.

Up next, ISIS claims responsibility for the Easter Sunday massacre on Christians in Sri Lanka.

First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 25 in Boston where a Florida judge has ordered a video police say shows New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft paying for sex not be released publicly for now. The judge accepted arguments by Kraft's attorneys that releasing the video could harm chances for a fair trial. He says it should not be handed to the media as a public record until the jury is seated, a plea agreement is reached or the state drops the case.

And this is a live look at Detroit from Fox 2. The big story there tonight, auto safety regulators expanded investigation into malfunctioning airbag controls to include 12.3 million vehicles. They say the bags may not inflate in a crash. As many as five deaths are already blamed on this problem. The probe covers parts installed in Toyota, Honda, Kia, Hyundai, Mitsubishi and Fiat-Chrysler vehicles from 2010 through 2019 model years.

That is tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Welcome back to a gorgeous night here at the White House.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says he wants to name a new settlement in the Golan Heights after President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BENJAMIN NETANYAHU, ISRAELI PRIME MINISTER: All Israelis were deeply moved when President Trump made a start (ph) decision to recognize Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights. Therefore after the Passover holiday I intend to bring to the government a resolution calling for a new community on the Golan Heights named after President Donald J. Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)
